Dr. Luke Hunter, President and Chief Conservation Officer at Panthera, a global organization dedicated to wild cat conservation that supports Kope Lion, hailed the event as "truly unique" in an interview with the BBC. While mentioning cases of lionesses adopting other lion cubs, Dr. Hunter emphasized the unprecedented nature of this interspecies interaction. He added, "I know of no other case - between any large cat, for that matter - where the species has adopted or nursed the cub of another species."

The Police Federation has raised a complaint with the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC). Allegedly, the police utilized the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act (RIPA) to uncover the identity of the informant. It is claimed that an application was submitted after the publication of the story, which was sourced from an internal police report about institutionalized discrimination within the department. When asked, a Cleveland Police spokesperson declined to either confirm or deny the alleged RIPA application to monitor the telephone communications of three journalists, a police officer, a solicitor, and the former chairman of Cleveland Police Federation. Editor Peter from the Northern Echo did not comment further on this matter.

A recent study conducted among employees and managers revealed that a significant proportion of new fathers, around 25%, opted not to take any paternity leave. Additionally, the research showed that less than 10% of new fathers took more than the mandatory two weeks of leave they were entitled to. The Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM), responsible for the research, attributed this trend to deeply-rooted employer attitudes and the new fathers' concerns about being able to afford a longer leave. To address this issue, the government planned to introduce new legislation in April 2015 that would enable parents to share their maternity and paternity leave. However, the ILM cautioned that simply implementing new policies may not be enough to drive change if employer attitudes remain unchanged. Charles Elvin, the chief executive of the ILM, emphasized that while shared parental leave could enhance opportunities for women to advance into leadership roles, the cultural norms prevalent in organizations continue to hinder the uptake of statutory paternity and additional paternity leave.

The Irish Coastguard Rescue Helicopter 116 carried four individuals during its tragic crash on 14 March. Despite being rescued from the sea, Captain Dara Fitzpatrick tragically lost her life. Efforts to locate the remaining crew members are ongoing, with divers only recently permitted to operate due to adverse weather conditions. Garda Superintendent Tony Healy mentioned that the divers are actively conducting search operations on the seabed, emphasizing their commitment to recovering the crew members. Jurgen Whyte, Chief Inspector with the IAAIU, confirmed the successful retrieval of the data recorder from the seabed near Blackrock, which will soon undergo analysis in Dublin before being forwarded to the UK's air accident investigation branch.

More than 130,000 visitors have attended the exhibition since its opening in October. One of the highlights is The Lacemaker, considered Vermeer's smallest work, which was borrowed from The Louvre and is currently on view in the UK for the first time. In response to the high demand, the museum will be extending its operating hours for the final two weeks of the exhibition. The surge in popularity of the exhibition, titled Vermeer's Women: Secrets and Silence, is largely attributed to the inclusion of The Lacemaker. Curator Betsy Wiseman explained, "The Louvre rarely loans this painting as it holds almost as much significance in their collection as the Mona Lisa. It is a piece that many people specifically travel to the Louvre to see." Other notable works in the exhibition include A Lady At The Virginals With A Gentleman (The Music Lesson) from The Royal Collection, and A Young Woman Seated At A Virginal from the National Gallery, London.

Helen Bailey, aged 51, was discovered deceased in a tank on her property in Royston, Hertfordshire, in July 2016 after being last seen on April 11. Ian Stewart, her partner, has pleaded not guilty to the charge of murder. Witness Edward Farmer initially testified at St Albans Crown Court that he spotted her in a vehicle in Broadstairs, Kent, sometime between mid-April and June but later acknowledged this sighting could have occurred several weeks earlier. He described seeing Ms. Bailey on Charlotte Street close to her vacation home in what appeared to be a dark-colored Range Rover or a similar 4x4 vehicle, driving solo, contradicting allegations made by the defense that she had been abducted by two aggressive individuals who transported her to Broadstairs. Mr. Farmer stated that the purported sighting took place "approximately five, possibly six weeks prior to his police interview" when questioned about its timing.

Minutes from the central bank's October meeting revealed officials' concerns about stock market volatility and global economic fragility, although they were cautious about expressing these worries to avoid misinterpretation. Despite this, policymakers expressed confidence in the robustness of the US economy, leading them to terminate their quantitative easing (QE) program. This initiative involved the Federal Reserve purchasing bonds to maintain lower long-term interest rates and stimulate consumer spending. The minutes highlighted the officials' consensus that the economy possessed sufficient underlying strength to continue progressing towards full employment. Following the announcement, US markets responded with restrained reactions, as the Dow Jones experienced a brief uptick before slipping back into negative territory. To reassure investors of the Fed's commitment to its decisions, efforts were made to emphasize the central bank's adherence to its planned trajectory.

Robin Waistell claimed that his attempts to sell his home in Maesteg were hindered by the rail body's failure to address the invasive weed on the neighboring bank. This legal case was seen as a significant one for homeowners dealing with similar knotweed issues from railway embankments. Network Rail has stated that they will be closely examining the court's decision, and they were denied immediate permission to appeal the verdict. Following the loss of the case in Cardiff to Mr Waistell and his neighbor, Network Rail could potentially face substantial legal expenses amounting to six figures. Widower Mr Waistell, aged 70, had relocated to the bungalow from Spain following his wife's passing, hoping to sell the property and return to sunny Spain, but was unable to do so due to the knotweed problem on the adjacent Network Rail property.

During his confirmation hearing, Rex Tillerson's comments are likely to escalate tensions with Beijing due to their ongoing construction of artificial islands on reefs in disputed waters. Recent images showing military installations on these islands have raised concerns. Drawing parallels to Russia's annexation of Crimea, Tillerson emphasized the need to address China's actions by halting island development and restricting access to them. Beijing's island-building efforts have triggered unease among neighboring nations like Vietnam, the Philippines, Taiwan, Malaysia, and Brunei, all of which have conflicting territorial claims in the South China Sea. Despite an international tribunal's ruling against China's claims in response to a case brought by the Philippines, Beijing refused to recognize the decision.

The possibility of introducing index-linked bonds in the near future has been disclosed, pending favorable market conditions. This revelation follows the council's achievement of being the first in Scotland to receive a credit rating. Moody's Investors Service has affirmed an Aa2 issuer credit rating. Aberdeen has highlighted that the intended funding will bolster a £1 billion capital program. Jennifer Laing, the council leader, emphasized the potential significance of a bond issuance for the city, following the credit rating assignment. She expressed pride in the council's pioneering role in innovating public sector finance. Laing underlined the proactive stance in securing capital funding to safeguard the revenue budget, essential for service provision.

The terms and conditions of GMB Scotland members in the offshore sector are reportedly being targeted, prompting officers to request approval from the regional committee to survey members governed by the Offshore Contractors Agreement regarding potential strike actions. In a parallel move, Unite also disclosed a comparable initiative recently. The decline in oil prices has led numerous North Sea oil and gas companies to announce job cuts and salary reductions. The decision by GMB follows unsuccessful discussions between the unions and the Offshore Contractors Association (OCA) last Friday. The Offshore Contractors Agreement applies to employees involved in a range of activities such as mechanical, electrical, construction, maintenance, design, project engineering, fabrication, and decommissioning services. John Kelly, a regional representative for GMB Scotland, expressed concerns, highlighting what he described as the deliberate attempt by certain oil companies and contractors to undermine their members' terms and conditions through what he termed as 'blatant opportunism.'

In the first half, The Saddlers appeared more likely to score first as Albion's goalkeeper Jon McLaughlin managed to block attempts from Paul Downing and Romaine Sawyers. Burton almost scored when Stuart Beavon made his way into Walsall's box but missed the target, hitting the side-netting instead. Even with Wigan's victory over Bury, Albion's lead at the top was reduced to two points, as Walsall maintained their fourth position. Nigel Clough, the manager of Burton Albion, mentioned in an interview with BBC Radio Derby that the game was evenly matched and not expected to be a high-scoring affair. Despite few opportunities, they secured a clean sheet and earned another point. He acknowledged their improved ball control in their previous match but highlighted the team's strength in defensive solidarity. Walsall's head coach, Sean O'Driscoll, also shared his thoughts on the game.

During discussions with President Barack Obama at the White House, the prime minister brought up the topic of existing extradition rules which critics argue favor the US by requiring less evidence for the extradition of UK nationals. A senior judge in 2011 deemed the rules fair to British citizens. The BBC's political editor, Nick Robinson, reported that Prime Minister Cameron addressed concerns regarding the practical implementation of these rules during two hours of talks at the White House. Currently on a three-day official visit to the United States, Cameron's discussions come amid heightened scrutiny of the 2003 US-UK extradition treaty following the controversial cases of British citizens, including Christopher Tappin and Gary McKinnon. Various groups, such as Parliament's Joint Committee on Human Rights, have called for the treaty to be renegotiated, citing its imbalance.

Fiscal Kombat is a game where the player embodies Mr. Melenchon, engaging in battles with oligarchs and rival politicians on the streets. The main goal is to collect money from the wealthy in order to fund Melenchon's policies. The player's objective is to acquire as much money as possible while evading attacks from the rich. Some of the notable opponents, also known as "bosses," include Nicolas Sarkozy, Christine Lagarde, Jerome Cahuzac, Liliane Bettencourt, Emmanuel Macron, and Francois Fillon. Le Monde reported that the game was developed by Melenchon supporters who congregated on Jeuxvideo.com's 18-25 chatroom. The candidate himself has wholeheartedly embraced the game.

The proposed merger between Bouygues Telecom and SFR, owned by Vivendi, aims to establish the leading mobile service provider in France, resulting in a market with only three key players. Altice, the owner of Numericable in France, has also presented a bid for SFR, with the exact amount undisclosed. Bouygues Telecom and SFR rank as the second and third largest mobile operators in France, and if combined, they would surpass Orange to claim the top spot. However, the approval of competition authorities in both France and the EU is required before the merger can proceed. Similar to Telefonica's bid for E-Plus in Germany, which raised concerns in Brussels about competition, industry analysts view the offer from Bouygues as part of a broader consolidation trend in the mobile sector.

A 60-year-old ex-lecturer at the University of Chester, named Doreen Collyer, was fatally attacked while scuba diving near Perth during the weekend. According to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), she was believed to have been killed by a 16-foot (5-meter) great white shark. Her husband, David Collyer, described her as a wonderful individual and beloved spouse. The couple had relocated to Australia from Neston, Cheshire, nearly five years ago. Mrs. Collyer was certified with an advanced open water qualification. ABC mentioned that her diving companion was able to retrieve her from the water, but she passed away from her wounds on the spot. Professor Annette McIntosh-Scott, from the University of Chester, expressed that Mrs. Collyer was an immensely valued and cherished faculty member who had dedicated 15 years to the Faculty of Health and Social Care. She will always be remembered for her genuine dedication and enthusiasm for teaching and child healthcare, with her students being central to her focus.

Hurricane Gert is believed to have carried a native American bird across the Atlantic as it was migrating to South America, according to Martin Cade from Portland Bird Observatory. This rare sighting marks the first time such a warbler has been seen in England. These birds are a common sight in the US, annually migrating between North and South America. Cade speculated that the warbler might have been swept off course by storms in the Caribbean and blown to Europe with strong winds. Another sighting was reported in Mizen Head, Ireland. Described as robin-sized, the bird was seen feeding actively, prompting predictions that it would stock up before continuing its journey to Spain and Africa. Bird enthusiasts from various regions, including the Midlands, South Wales, and Yorkshire, flocked to witness this extraordinary event as news of the bird's arrival spread on Monday.

The 28-year-old Chilean player, who secured a pivotal victory for Arsenal in the FA Cup semi-final against Manchester City last Sunday, still has a year remaining on his contract with the Gunners but has not yet committed to a new agreement. Arsène Wenger, the French manager, expressed confidence that the player will remain at the club, ruling out a transfer to any other Premier League team. While Wenger himself has not confirmed his own continuation at the helm of Arsenal beyond this season, he is actively engaged in identifying potential transfer recruits for the upcoming season. Despite being 67 years old and facing the conclusion of his current contract, he has been presented with the option of a fresh two-year extension. "I am fully dedicated to working on the present and future prospects of the club until the final day of the season," Wenger stated. "Identifying transfer targets forms a crucial part of shaping the club's future," he emphasized, adding, "Speculations regarding my own future are part and parcel of the ongoing discussions."

Gene Palmer is the second prison staff member apprehended in connection with the prison break, following Joyce Mitchell who has already faced charges for assisting in the escape. The escapees, Richard Matt and David Sweat, utilized power tools to break free from the Clinton Correctional Facility. A widespread search operation is currently in progress to locate the duo, both of whom are convicted murderers. Mr. Palmer was taken into custody after his court appearance where he was charged with promoting prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence, and official misconduct. His attorney, Andrew Brockway, acknowledged that his client did transport the hamburger meat but claimed ignorance about the tools hidden inside it or the inmates' escape plan. Mr. Brockway mentioned that his client regrets his actions and intends to plead not guilty. According to Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie, Ms. Mitchell played a vital role in the escape and was instrumental in providing assistance to the prisoners.

The H3 initiative has consolidated administrative services for multiple authorities in Hampshire and Oxfordshire, aiming to generate annual savings of up to £5m. However, issues such as payroll inaccuracies have arisen since its inception in 2014, as highlighted by the Police Federation. Hampshire's Police and Crime Commissioner (PCC) has expressed optimism that the investment will result in enhancements by May. According to a report presented to PCC Michael Lane, H3 has led to challenges in recruitment, staff sickness management, and burdensome back office tasks for police officers, impacting their efficiency. Instances of payroll errors, including incorrect payments to 1,300 officers in February 2016 and misjudged allowances in March, have also been reported. Additionally, there was a threefold increase in payment delays to Hampshire County Council's suppliers in 2015 due to the new system. Hampshire Police Federation chairman John Apter has voiced concerns about the system's implementation.

Police detained a 22-year-old from Sleaford and a 25-year-old from Bracknell on Thursday over their suspected involvement in multiple attempts to breach the Microsoft network from January to March this year. Both individuals were charged under the Computer Misuse Act in the UK, which prohibits unauthorized computer access. According to the authorities, the duo were members of a larger group planning to hack into the software company's systems with the intention of stealing client information. The South East Regional Organised Crime Unit (Serocu) conducted the arrests and seized electronic devices as part of the operation, as stated by Detective Sergeant Rob Bryant.

During an IMF meeting in Washington, Ms. Lagarde stated that the UK's approach to its economic situation has proven effective. She highlighted the similarity between the IMF's forecast of the future deficit and the Office for Budget Responsibility's more optimistic projection, explaining that the discrepancy was due to different calculation methods. Her comments were made while George Osborne and German finance minister Wolfgang Schaeuble were also present on the panel. Ms. Lagarde pointed out that during election years, forecasts tend to be cautious and do not assume announced measures will necessarily materialize. According to her, the UK has successfully struck a balance between spending cuts and revenue generation, leading to positive outcomes evident in growth rates compared to other European countries.

Transport for London (TfL) is planning to introduce new requirements such as an English language exam, map-reading test, fixed landline, and advanced booking options, which has prompted concerns from Uber about potential changes to their service. Black cab drivers have called for stricter regulations to be imposed, as shown by recent protests at City Hall. The Uber app utilizes GPS to match customers with nearby drivers and offers fare estimates, with cashless transactions linked to registered bank accounts. TfL aims to enhance industry standards amid rapid growth in private hire services and technology advancements, while Uber warns that the proposed measures could lead to higher prices and increased traffic congestion.

On average, "superfans" of music festivals in the UK spend approximately £581 annually, choosing VIP passes and upgraded camping. Most of them are male and are more inclined to purchase music in CD or download format compared to other consumers. These statistics were derived from a survey of 504 UK residents who had participated in at least one festival within the past year. According to the survey conducted by ticketing website Eventbrite, these dedicated fans significantly influence the music festival industry by recommending music and events to others. They make up 28% of festival attendees, with 54% open to attending events alone. Their average spending per event surpasses that of casual fans by £45, although their loyalty is not steadfast, as 46% believe festivals are becoming excessively commercial. The UK hosts over 100 music festivals annually, ranging from prominent ones like Glastonbury and T In The Park to smaller-scale events.

The FTSE 100 share index surged to fresh 11-month highs initially but then experienced a slight drop to close nearly unchanged at 6,680.69, a marginal decline of 2.17 points or 0.03%. On the other hand, the more domestically focused FTSE 250 index advanced by 68.75 points, or 0.4%, to reach 16,775.14. Galliford Try provided a boost to the property sector, resulting in a positive response from investors despite the sector facing a significant sell-off post-Brexit. The housebuilder's announcement that it anticipated meeting its full-year profit targets led to an 8.5% increase in its share value. Similarly, financial stocks, which were adversely affected following the referendum, also displayed a positive trend. For instance, insurer Aviva witnessed a rise of 4.26% in its shares, while Lloyds Banking Group was also performing well on the day.

In April, the boat suffered extensive damage when a British submarine accidentally entangled its fishing nets and dragged it back 18 miles from the County Down coast. The skipper mentioned that his crew luckily escaped unscathed, and estimated the repair costs at around £10,000. Despite initially refraining from commenting on submarine activities, the Ministry of Defence (MoD) has now acknowledged the involvement of a UK submarine in the incident. The Royal Navy confirmed that the MV Karen was the damaged boat and attributed the accident to the submarine's failure to properly identify it as a fishing vessel with active nets in the water. Minister for the Armed Forces Penny Mordaunt expressed deep regret over the incident and subsequent delays in addressing the situation.

Kian Delos Santos was fatally shot by police under the pretense that he was linked to drug activities and had resisted arrest. However, video surveillance indicates that the 17-year-old was forcibly taken away by plainclothes officers. The available evidence suggests that he was on his knees, facing down when he was killed. A large crowd gathered for his funeral in Manila, displaying signs urging an end to the brutal anti-drug campaign led by President Duterte, a campaign that has garnered support from those frustrated with drug-related crimes in the Philippines. During the funeral procession from the church to the cemetery where Kian was laid to rest, nuns, priests, and numerous children chanted "justice for Kian, justice for all," as reported by Reuters news agency. At the Mass, Kian's father, Saldy, briefly spoke, defending his son's innocence and expressing his outrage towards the police, questioning their humanity and suggesting they seek solace in churches.

Less than a year ago, construction began on a new 72km (44 mile) lane parallel to a section of the existing canal, enabling two-way traffic and accommodating larger vessels. During a recent trial run, numerous container ships from various countries successfully passed through it with helicopter and naval vessel escorts as part of the security protocol. The canal development is significant due to its location near the Sinai Peninsula, a known hotspot for Islamic militants responsible for numerous casualties since the political upheaval in 2013. The original Suez Canal, connecting the Mediterranean and Red Seas, has operated for close to 150 years. President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi of Egypt anticipates that expanding this vital trade route will enhance commerce, generating more job opportunities throughout the nation. Currently responsible for managing 7% of global maritime trade, the Suez Canal is among the busiest shipping lanes worldwide.

During his tenure from 1976 to 1990 as the head of St William's in Market Weighton, East Riding of Yorkshire, James Carragher was sentenced to seven years in 1993 and 14 years in 2004 for sexual offenses. Despite being charged with 50 indecent assault offenses from the 1970s to the 1990s, he denies the allegations. The trial also involves two other former staff members of the now-closed home for boys with behavioral issues, which was managed by the Catholic De La Salle order. The prosecution, led by Richard Wright QC, stated that Carragher seemed to have a disturbing interest in young boys. Wright emphasized that Carragher used a facade of respectability to conceal his true intentions.

The 23-year-old agreed to a three-year deal following his transfer from Vitoria Setubal for an undisclosed amount. Speaking to Rangers TV, he acknowledged the need to adjust to a new country and lifestyle but expressed confidence in his ability to succeed. Committed to aiding his team in securing victories, he emphasized Rangers' obligation to achieve greatness. Cardoso, previously a member of the Portuguese Under-21 squad, played 23 matches for Vitoria Setubal in the previous season after switching from Benfica. Following Bruno Alves' arrival from Cagliari, the young defender is the second Portuguese center-back to join Rangers this season. In addition, midfielder Dalcio from Benfica has also joined the team at Ibrox on loan.

Long-standing Mugabe critic Morgan Tsvangirai and former Vice-President Joice Mujuru have announced their intention to collaborate in the upcoming election, though the specific presidential candidate is yet to be determined. The current President Mugabe, aged 93, has been in authority since the nation gained independence from Britain in 1980 and has expressed his desire to run for re-election. Mr. Tsvangirai shared with reporters, "This marks the initial phase in forming a broad coalition to challenge Zanu-PF leading up to the next election." The formation of this coalition is a crucial initial move in unifying a fractured opposition. Should this collaboration prove successful, it would be the first instance of President Mugabe facing a consolidated opposition of this magnitude since assuming power in 1980.

During a meeting with a group of MEPs on Wednesday, Jean-Claude Juncker expressed his support for democratic processes and assured that he would honor Scotland's decision. When queried about the prospect of Catalonia and Scotland seeking EU membership, he emphasized that mere correspondence wouldn't suffice for EU accession. Specifically addressed by Catalan MEP Josep Maria Terricabras regarding the upcoming Scottish independence referendum in September, Juncker reiterated his stance on democratic principles and refrained from preempting the discussion. He affirmed his commitment to respecting the outcome of the Scottish referendum, reiterating that EU membership involves more than just written communication. Responding to Scottish UKIP MEP David Coburn's inquiry during a subsequent meeting regarding Scotland's EU membership in case of independence, Mr. Juncker deferred the decision-making authority to the UK.

According to the report by the Crimson, the students in a Facebook chat forum made inappropriate jokes about child abuse, sexual assault, paedophilia, and the Holocaust, as well as directed racial slurs at minorities. The punitive measures taken by Harvard in response to this behavior have been criticized by advocates of free speech as "draconian." The chat forum, an offshoot of a larger group initially created by incoming Harvard students, was intended for sharing more mature content such as memes. Aspiring members were required to submit a "provocative" meme to be considered for the subgroup. Harvard officials became aware of the subgroup and initiated an investigation shortly after its formation.

Community leaders in Santa Clara County have taken the initial step to gather signatures to remove Judge Aaron Persky from office next year. The move comes in the wake of public outcry over Judge Persky's controversial decision in June 2016 to give Stanford University student Brock Turner a lenient six-month sentence for a sexual assault incident, instead of a possible 14-year term. Turner was released after serving just three months in a county jail for the assault that took place in January 2015. The recall petition highlights the shock and dismay caused by the sentencing, emphasizing the need for a judge who prioritizes the protection of victims over offenders. Stanford law professor Michele Dauber, spearheading the recall campaign alongside 50 community figures, stressed the importance of combating rape culture and ensuring justice for women in the county.

Contestants at the yearly competition are given a five-minute window to craft their most impressive and elaborate falsehood. The victorious participant, George Kemp hailing from Maryport, Cumbria, was taken aback by his win due to battling a chest ailment. His winning narrative detailed an encounter with Donald Trump and his spouse at an underwater hotel. Kemp humorously recounted a fabricated tale involving fashioning a tiny submarine from his father's retired bubble car. Embarking on a journey to the Isle of Man, they crossed paths with various renowned figures aboard a Scottish submarine cleverly constructed from shortbread tins. Allegedly, Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond even managed to auction off a few of these large shortbread tin vessels to the United States. Previous year's victor, Mike Naylor, also known as Monkey Liar, secured second place, with Helen Jordan finishing third. Noteworthy champions from the past include comedian and TV personality Sue Perkins.

The survey revealed that just 28% of Welsh speakers had communicated in Welsh with their healthcare providers, such as GPs, dentists, and opticians. Ms. Huws expressed her hope that the report would mark a turning point in ensuring patients receive suitable healthcare according to their linguistic requirements. Government officials, responding positively to the report, committed to giving feedback within six months. The investigation, which drew from the input of over a thousand Welsh speakers, highlighted that 90% of participants believed they should have the option to use Welsh in interactions with the NHS across Wales. Testimonies from Welsh speakers in the inquiry indicated they felt uncomfortable and had difficulty articulating their issues to English-speaking medical professionals. The report contains 33 suggestions for the Welsh government, urging policymakers to set a strong directive for primary healthcare providers, along with an implementation strategy and schedule for enacting changes.

The legislation proposed seeks to overturn certain aspects of the 2016 Trade Union Act by altering existing limitations on strikes within various essential sectors in Wales, including the NHS, fire service, and schools. The UK government insists that matters concerning industrial relations fall under the jurisdiction of Westminster. Under the current UK law, strikes must have the support of at least 40% of the union members in a ballot. Despite this, members of the Welsh Assembly's Equality, Local Government and Communities Committee unanimously believe that the proposed changes are necessary to uphold Wales' collaborative way of working. Welsh Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford previously criticized any attempts by London authorities to interfere with the Welsh Trade Union Bill, calling it a "democratic outrage." The Welsh Labour Government contends that the UK government should not impose constraints on union activities within devolved services in Wales. The committee's report did not receive support from Conservative AM Janet Finch-Saunders, who dissented from the majority opinion.

11-year-old Evha Jannath fell from a water ride at Drayton Manor during a school trip. In response to the incident, similar rides at Alton Towers and Legoland Windsor have been temporarily shut down. Drayton Manor will remain closed on Friday for safety inspections. Merlin Entertainments, the company behind Legoland and Alton Towers, stated that the rides were closed immediately after learning about the tragic accident. Other amusement parks like Lightwater Valley and West Midland Safari Park have not taken such actions following the tragic incident.

An early mishap by Ally Gilchrist with an own goal, followed by a powerful shot from James Tavernier, cemented the Championship champions' lead. Andy Halliday furthered their advantage with a penalty goal, while Kenny Miller sealed the victory for Rangers in their fourth attempt at the trophy. Next on the agenda for Mark Warburton's team is a Scottish Cup semi-final against Celtic next Sunday. Rangers had faced challenges in the Challenge Cup under different formats, suffering defeats to Queen of the South, Raith Rovers, and Alloa Athletic. Securing the title marks a significant achievement as they gear up to face the Premiership leaders at the national stadium. A new and much-needed pitch will be in place at Hampden by then, addressing the issues that both Rangers and League One Peterhead faced on the substandard current surface. Despite the recent £200,000 investment on the pitch, it is set to be replaced after failing to meet expectations. At odds of 22-1, the part-time players of Peterhead had to contend with the inadequate conditions.

Members of the Royal College of Midwives (RCM) have unanimously voted in favor of taking strike action for a period of four hours. This marks the first instance of such action in the college's 134-year history. The Department of Health expressed disappointment at the decision and assured that efforts would be made in collaboration with trusts to maintain a safe level of service for mothers and babies. The Department also emphasized a willingness for open discussions. The RCM is keen on engaging in immediate discussions with the health minister to address the ongoing conflict. RCM NI director Bredagh Hughes clarified that midwives are advocating for equal treatment, seeking the 1% pay raise received by their counterparts in Wales, Scotland, and England. Hughes emphasized that the dispute is not directed towards women, but rather is with the department of health and employers. She further highlighted that emergency services would not be compromised during the strike, with provisions in place for full emergency coverage and the possibility of calling in picket line midwives if needed.

Tesco Bank reported that the actual number of current account customers affected by the fraud is less than half of the originally stated 20,000. Despite the attack, personal data remained secure, and all impacted accounts have been reimbursed. The bank identified the incident as a "systematic, sophisticated attack" and has reinstated online debit transactions for customers. CEO Benny Higgins mentioned that all affected customers have been refunded and online debit transaction suspensions have been lifted. Following the preventive actions taken to avoid illegal operations, current account holders were unable to make online payments using their debit cards. Mr. Higgins expressed regret for the distress caused by the issue and assured that the bank comprehends the nature of the attack.

Construction laborers must possess a CSCS card as evidence of their skills and understanding of health and safety protocols. However, a collaborative inquiry by BBC London and Newsnight uncovered instances of systematic fraud. Carl Rhymer from the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB) disclosed that approximately 6,000 cardholders would need to retake the examination. The CSCS (Construction Skills Certification Scheme) cards are widely regarded as the primary certification scheme in the UK for affirming the competence of construction workers, mandated by top construction firms in the UK along with notable projects like Crossrail and Heathrow. The investigation revealed that several test centers were providing assured passes in exchange for money, which allowed individuals with inadequate English proficiency to secure qualifications and access hazardous construction sites. The probe showcased Wep HSE in Ealing, where the renowned director Garet Estensen was observed reading exam responses from a large screen, guiding candidates by saying, "Follow my lead on the screen, everyone. I will vocalize the correct response." When presented with proof, Mr. Estensen opted not to respond. Two other centers implicated in the investigation were Future Training 4.

A ransom demand of 100 Bitcoin, equivalent to approximately $70,000 (£56,000; €66,000), was issued by hackers. Envoy Sigrid Kaag addressed the situation as Syria seemed to have failed to meet the Sunday deadline for removing its chemical arsenal from the country. Aiming for all of Syria's chemical weapons to be eliminated by the end of June, the Russian-US agreement was established in response to a sarin rocket attack near Damascus that resulted in numerous casualties last year. The process of eliminating Syria's chemical weapons is being handled by a multinational team overseen by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). Even though the UN's deadline for completely getting rid of Syria's chemical weapons is set for 30 June, the government of Damascus had committed to finishing the removal of its stockpile by 27 April, following previous missed deadlines. Emphasizing the necessity of expediting the destruction of the remaining chemical weapons material, Ms. Kaag, the leader of the OPCW-UN, pointed out that while a significant portion of the chemical weapons material has been removed, it is yet to be destroyed to meet the 30 June deadline.
